title: Root Repulsion and Faster Solving for Very Sparse Polynomials Over 𝑝-adic Fields
abstract:
Abstract.
For any fixed field K∈{ℚ2,ℚ3,ℚ5,…}𝐾subscriptℚ2subscriptℚ3subscriptℚ5…K\!\in\!\{\mathbb{Q}_{2},\mathbb{Q}_{3},\mathbb{Q}_{5},\ldots\}, we prove that
all polynomials f∈ℤ​[x]𝑓ℤdelimited-[]𝑥f\!\in\!\mathbb{Z}[x] with exactly 333 (resp. 222) monomial terms,
degree d𝑑d, and all coefficients having absolute value at most H𝐻H,
can be solved over K𝐾K within deterministic time log4+o​(1)⁡(d​H)​log3⁡(d)superscript4𝑜1𝑑𝐻superscript3𝑑\log^{4+o(1)}(dH)\log^{3}(d)
(resp. log2+o​(1)⁡(d​H)superscript2𝑜1𝑑𝐻\log^{2+o(1)}(dH)) in the classical Turing model: Our
underlying algorithm correctly counts the
number of roots of f𝑓f in K𝐾K, and for
each such root generates an approximation in ℚℚ\mathbb{Q} with logarithmic height
O​(log2⁡(d​H)​log⁡(d))𝑂superscript2𝑑𝐻𝑑O(\log^{2}(dH)\log(d)) that converges at a rate of
O​((1/p)2i)𝑂superscript1𝑝superscript2𝑖O\!\left((1/p)^{2^{i}}\right)
after i𝑖i steps of Newton iteration. We also prove significant speed-ups in
certain settings, a minimal spacing bound of p−O​(p​logp2⁡(d​H)​log⁡d)superscript𝑝𝑂𝑝subscriptsuperscript2𝑝𝑑𝐻𝑑p^{-O(p\log^{2}_{p}(dH)\log d)} for
distinct roots in ℂpsubscriptℂ𝑝\mathbb{C}_{p}, and even stronger repulsion when
there are nonzero degenerate roots in ℂpsubscriptℂ𝑝\mathbb{C}_{p}: p𝑝p-adic distance
p−O​(logp⁡(d​H))superscript𝑝𝑂subscript𝑝𝑑𝐻p^{-O(\log_{p}(dH))}. On the other hand, we prove that there is an explicit
family of tetranomials with distinct nonzero roots in ℤpsubscriptℤ𝑝\mathbb{Z}_{p} indistinguishable
in their first Ω​(d​logp⁡H)Ω𝑑subscript𝑝𝐻\Omega(d\log_{p}H) most significant base-p𝑝p digits.
